reaction.reactionmeddrallt: Red blood cell distribution width increased

summary.narrativeincludeclinical:
Combined initial and follow-up report received from the physician via the Clozaril patient monitoring services (CPMS - patient registry) on 29 Jul 2010 and 30 Jul 2010: This patient had medical history of high cholesterol and hyperlipidemia. He started Clozaril (clozapine) 50 mg for unknown indication from 13 Jul 2010. His pre Clozaril baseline values were unremarkable CK 169, troponin 0.01 and echo was good. In Jul 2010, his heart rate was at 93 which was same as baseline, no fever, eosinophils were "ok" and also has gastrointestinal symptoms (possible viral gastroenteritis). Now he was showing signs of cardiomyopathy. Troponin level on 21 Jul 2010 was normal; on 28 Jul 2010 was 1.13 and then the value decreased to 0.08 on 29 Jul 2010. Echo done on 30 Jul 2010 showed decreased systolic function in comparison to baseline but still within normal range. GI symptoms were now "ok". The patient did not required hospitalisation. As a precaution Clozaril therapy was discontinued on 30 Jul 2010. The physician suspected the causal relation between the events and Clozaril. No additional information was provided.
Follow-up report received from physician on 29 Nov 2012: The patient had the medical history of bipolar disorder and depression. The patient was treated for two weeks in Jul 2010 (unspecified date) but discontinued on 29 Jul 2010 due to rise in troponin and reduction in cardiac function. On an unknown date, electrocardiogram showed reduction in cardiac function. On 29 Jul 2010, the patient’s laboratory revealed that monocytes was 1.2, neutrophil was 8.4, white cell count was 11.4. On 08 Sep 2010, the patient tried for suicide attempt. On 08 Sep 2010, the patient was found inside a motor vehicle with hose pipe running from the exhaust to the window. He had an obstructed airway and glasgow coma scale (GCF) of 9. The patient required to admit in intrinsic care unit (ICU) and hyperbaric treatment. On 08 Sep 2010, the patient’s laboratory revealed that salicylate <0.36, albumin was 31, calcium was 1.64 mmol, chloride was 113mmol, creatine kinase was 1102, potassium was 6.2 mmol, hemoglobin, 110 g/l, red blood cell distribution was 13.6%, monocytes was 1.0, troponin was 1.41, white cell count was 16.6. On 09 Sep 2010, the patient’s laboratory revealed that albumin 27 g/l, calcium 1.75 mmol, chloride 119 mmol, creatine kinase 1917 IU/l, potassium 6.2 mmol/l, hemoglobin 110 g/l, red blood cell distribution 14.1 %, red blood cell 3.62 and troponin 4.04. On 10 Sep 2010, the patient’s laboratory revealed that albumin was 26 g/l, alkaline phosphatase was 38 IU/l, calcium 1.89 mmol, chloride 111 mmol, creatine kinase was 1651 IU/l, phosphate 0.55 mmol, urea 1.9 mmol, hemoglobin was 109 g/l, red blood cell distribution was 14.3 %, mean platelet volume 10.9, monocytes 1.1, red blood cell 3.62 and total protein 48. On 11 Sep 2010, the patient’s laboratory revealed that albumin was 28 g/l, calcium 2.02 mmol, chloride 111 mmol, creatine kinase 1707 IU/l, phosphate 1.50 mmol, urea 0.9 mmol, hemoglobin 113 g/l, red blood cell distribution 13.4 %, mean platelet volume 10.3, total protein 51 g/l and red blood cell 3.81. On 15 Oct 2010, the patient’s laboratory revealed that calcium 2.56 mmol, phosphate 0.73 mmol, red blood cell distribution 13.9 %, lymphocytes 3.8 and mean platelet volume 11.1. On 28 Nov 2012, it was also showed insufficient tricuspid valve. Treatment with Clozaril was discontinued on 29 Jul 2010. Seriousness of the events suicide attempt, glasgow coma scale 9 and obstructed airway was reported as hospitalization and for other events it was not reported. Outcome and causality of the events was not reported.
